awd_titl_txt: An Experimental Investigation of the Synthesis of Complex Organic Molecules in Interstellar Analog Ices
awd_abstract_narration:
This project studies how complex organic molecules (COM) -- organic molecules containing atoms of carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, and nitrogen -- are formed in the material between the stars (the "interstellar medium", or ISM).  The team will use laboratory experiments to study how COMs form on ice-coated grains like those expected to exist in the ISM.  Some of these COMs might serve as 'molecular clocks' allowing us to unravel the history of cold molecular clouds and star forming regions.  The PI and his students will experimentally determine just how complex we should expect interstellar molecules to become. Any COM discovered in these laboratory simulations will a candidate for future astronomical searches of this molecule in the ISM.  This project might also bring us closer to understanding the extent to which key classes of COMs might have been manufactured in the ISM and eventually delivered to the young Earth via meteorites.  The PI and his students will also organize interdisciplinary "laboratory astrophysics" workshops, work to broaden participation of native Hawai'ians in research and educational activities, and engage in public outreach activities. 

These goals will be achieved by systematically replicating the conditions of ice-coated interstellar grains within cold molecular clouds and toward high- and low-mass star forming regions.  The team will utilize an ultra-high vacuum surface scattering machine to expose interstellar ice analog samples in various simulated environments, with temperatures as low as 10 K, and including exposure to ionizing ultraviolet (Lyman-alpha) radiation. The novel technology of fragment-free vacuum ultraviolet photoionization within a space simulation chamber, along with several complementary detection schemes, will be used to probe the synthesis of COMs in ISM conditions.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit


Our program exploring the formation of complex organic molecules (COMs) via interaction of interstellar analog ices with ionizing radiation in a novel space simulation chamber has been extremely productive (P1-P20). We  commissioned a next generation ultra-high vacuum surface scattering machine to systematically explore the formation of COMs in the interstellar medium (ISM) by exposing ice analog samples relevant to molecular clouds and star forming regions to ionizing radiation in form of energetic electrons generated in the track of galactic cosmic rays (GCR). This was accomplished by incorporating for the first time fragment free photoionization (PI) of the subliming molecules during the temperature programmed desorption (TPD) in conjunction with reflectron time of flight mass spectrometry (ReTOFMS) in a space simulation chamber (PI-ReTOF-MS); this technology was combined with on line and in situ infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) of the irradiated ices along with solving the differential equations of the temporal evolution of the newly formed molecules to extract formation rates and transformative reaction mechanisms. Four key findings (F1-F4) shall be highlighted.

 

F1: Utilizing PI-ReTOF-MS, the first isomer-selective formation mechanisms of the simplest representatives of a key class of COMs in interstellar analog ices - aldehydes (HCOR) and their enol isomers (RHCCH(OH)) - were extracted (Fig. 1): acetaldehyde (HCOCH3) - vinyl alcohol (H2C=CH(OH)) and propanal (HCOC2H5) - 1-propenol  (H3HC=C(OH)H). Combined with astrochemical modeling, this study revealed a vigorous cosmic-ray-driven non-equilibrium chemistry inside the ices at ultralow temperatures prior to sublimation of COMs into starforming regions, but not through radical-radical recombination in the warm-up phase of the irradiated ices as speculated for the last decades (P4, P6). The concept of a GCR triggered chemistry was expanded to explain the recent detection of propylene oxide (c-C3H6O) toward Sgr B2(N) (Fig. 1) (P14), of carboxylic acids such as Vitamin B3 in meteorites (P1, P2, P16, P20), along with interstellar C3 and C4 COMs (C3H8O (propanol, methyl ethyl ether) and C4H8O (n-butanal, i-butanal)), which act as flavonoids in chocolate (P17) (Fig. 2).

F2: These investigations were expanded to rationalize the synthetic routes to a chemically more diverse class of COMs: amides (RCONH2) (P7, P8) and their methylated derivative N-methyl formamide (P19). Urea (H2NCONH2) - a fundamental building block leading to amidetype polymers in prebiotic chemistry - was identified isomer selectively via PI-ReTOF-MS as a product of a cosmic-ray triggered exposure of carbon monoxide (CO) - ammonia (NH3) ices. Higher radiation doses lead to mass growth and synthesis of molecules with amide (-NH-CO-) moieties.

F3: Fatty acids (P20) represent critical building blocks of triglycerides and phospholipids, which in turn are a major component of cell membranes.  Exploiting PI-ReTOF-MS, we characterized mass growth processes starting from methane (CH4) leading to alkanes and their unsaturated counterpart with up to 12 carbon atoms (P3, P11, P15). The mechanisms involve radical - radical recombination along with hitherto neglected insertions of electronically excited carbene (CH2) at temperatures as low as 5 K.

F4: We exposed the underlying mechanisms of formation of the simplest alcohol - ether isomer pair - ethanol (C2H5OH) and dimethyl ether (CH3OCH3) (P9, P13) - and the most primitive amines methylamine (CH3NH2) and ethylamine (C2H5NH2) (P10) exploiting isomer selective PIReTOF- MS studies combined with isotopic labeling. A comparison of these branching ratios with astronomical observations suggests that methanol and methane represent key precursors to both isomers. These studies were expanded to define hitherto unknown synthetic routes to the ethyl methyl ether molecule  (CH3OCH2CH3) as detected in star forming regions (P18).

 

 

Broader Impact

Human Resource Development. We trained 11 scientists in the fields of laboratory astrophysics, astronomy, and astrochemistry demonstrating our commitment to educate scientists capable of assuming leading roles in US science in the future. 100 % of the Native Hawaiians and Female Scientists involved in our laboratory as undergraduate students are continuing careers as graduate students at U.S. Universities (Columbia, UH Manoa, Yale). Our (international) collaborative training activities involved well-reputed theoreticians, astrochemical modelers, and physical organic astrochemists.

Educational Outreach. The PI organized the workshop entitled Laboratory Astrophysics (ICE 2015) to promote new experimental methods probing the interaction of ionizing radiation, neutral atoms, and radicals with surfaces of solids in the ISM and in our Solar System. With close to 70 participants, this workshop attracted senior researchers (plenary lecturers), novices, and underrepresented minorities (women; 15 %) thus demonstrating the unique impact in the community. Second, the PI organized the symposium Expanding the Frontiers in Condensed Phase Astrochemistry: Electron Transfer Processes in Ices and Catalysis on Interstellar Grains (ACS 2017). With close to 80 participants - among them 25 % females and 20 % undergraduate students - this symposium was immensely successful at bridging the disciplinary boundaries that has separated the planetary sciences, chemistry, and astronomy communities.
